Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Operation and Control of Power System Networks with Increased DG Penetration

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Efficient Operation and Control of Power System Networks with Increase Distributed Generation Penetration
ECCS No: 0901851

ABSTRACT

The objective of this research is to develop insight into modeling of Distributed Generation (DG) particularly Renewable Energy Resources for network penetration, incorporating MW and MVAr demand response under load variability; to develop a value based optimization tool for integration of DG interconnection; to develop new performances metrics for evaluation of reliability, efficiency and congestion management of power system . The approach is aimed at developing improved models of DG and loads for grid penetration, Renewable Energy Resources response to demand system and control data approximate and determination of limits as input to overall optimized problems design of performance indices, metrics, and system studies for different scenarios associated with DG for optimum energy of the distribution or sub transmission.

Intellectual Merit: The research will use a computational approach to evaluate the impact of DG on network operation. A preferred method of marginal benefits of DG as a function of Location Marginal Price for voltage stability changes will be developed utilizing interior point and integer programming extensions. The robustness of the integrated scheme will be tested on a benchmark system.

Broader Impacts: The research will enhance optimization techniques for energy systems, thus improving system efficiency. It will further provide a contribution to the development of the autonomous Smart Grid under increased penetration of DG including alternative energy options. This is of benefit for the Nation's energy security and quality of life. The project will further facilitate training of minority students and have impact on educating the future power and energy workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Howard university Efficient Operation and control of power  system networks  with increased DG penetration  is aimed at designing  adequate models for renewable energy sources to account for  variability  and uncertainty in load . The probability density function that accounts for variability using Rayleigh and Gamma probability distribution function were evaluated to account for the radiance changes in solar power and wind velocity in wind power. These account for improved performance of available power for DG based distribution networks to meet different   load models under different contingencies. The performance measure of the DG based grid requires optimization techniques that account for discrete variables and randomness of the resources. To this end we reviewed the potential  of  stochastic optimization and evolution-programming techniques  to  handle the new features of DG based grid. The chanced constrained stochastic optimization method and evolution-programming optimization such as Genetic algorithm has been developed and tested in carrying out generation dispatch to meet the random changes in load. The developed scheme has been  tested successfully on medium sized grids   and we have obtained satisfactory results. We believe the algorithm   will be tested on large-scale systems with satisfactory results.  With the results obtained so far, we are confident that future electric grid design and construction will benefit from the promising preliminary works of this project.

During the research we developed three  matrices  for valuing  DG based distribution  networks .  They are  resilience ,  reliability and  sustainability as well as cost  and benefit analysis. Our findings realizes that  DG based  networks will improve reliability and stability of the overall network whie reducing economic costs of power system operation. Additionally, the results  so far provide a research  in large  scale for   deciding   to  what extent  does one   develop   DG  based  network  compared to CG based  networks .We also discovered  that accuracy of the model is an important contribution to the overall performance of the DG based grd.

  The research  project has provided the opportunity to develop  new curriculum in the power system  research which attract the  best and the brightest  young  students to  consider research and career in the power field . This  has led to development of  a new  fundamentals  of  energy systems at Howard for juniors student and  also  smart grid course  for graduates  students in Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. The materials from the   research are used in the courses. We believe that  broader impacts of the research   work has touched many students who participated in the research and the courses taught  by the  Principal Investigator during the life  of the grant . Several   students have completed  their  theses  and project and  are now  gainfully employed in the industry. The  projects results were  published  in refereed  journals and proceedings and  presented  at the IEEE conferences and workshops.  Summer  outreach programs were held  during the  project which used renewable energy resources with  hands on exercises.The  team based activities involve   graduate students, Research Experience Undergraduate and Pre- college student's  working in a team based environment to  validate different functions   in automation  for Distribu...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Howard university Efficient Operation and control of power system networks with increased DG penetration is aimed at designing adequate models for renewable energy sources to account for variability and uncertainty in load . The probability density function that accounts for variability using Rayleigh and Gamma probability distribution function were evaluated to account for the radiance changes in solar power and wind velocity in wind power. These account for improved performance of available power for DG based distribution networks to meet different load models under different contingencies. The performance measure of the DG based grid requires optimization techniques that account for discrete variables and randomness of the resources. To this end we reviewed the potential of stochastic optimization and evolution-programming techniques to handle the new features of DG based grid. The chanced constrained stochastic optimization method and evolution-programming optimization such as Genetic algorithm has been developed and tested in carrying out generation dispatch to meet the random changes in load. The developed scheme has been tested successfully on medium sized grids and we have obtained satisfactory results. We believe the algorithm will be tested on large-scale systems with satisfactory results. With the results obtained so far, we are confident that future electric grid design and construction will benefit from the promising preliminary works of this project. During the research we developed three matrices for valuing DG based distribution networks . They are resilience , reliability and sustainability as well as cost and benefit analysis. Our findings realizes that DG based networks will improve reliability and stability of the overall network whie reducing economic costs of power system operation. Additionally, the results so far provide a research in large scale for deciding to what extent does one develop DG based network compared to CG based networks .We also discovered that accuracy of the model is an important contribution to the overall performance of the DG based grd. The research project has provided the opportunity to develop new curriculum in the power system research which attract the best and the brightest young students to consider research and career in the power field . This has led to development of a new fundamentals of energy systems at Howard for juniors student and also smart grid course for graduates students in Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. The materials from the research are used in the courses. We believe that broader impacts of the research work has touched many students who participated in the research and the courses taught by the Principal Investigator during the life of the grant . Several students have completed their theses and project and are now gainfully employed in the industry. The projects results were published in refereed journals and proceedings and presented at the IEEE conferences and workshops. Summer outreach programs were held during the project which used renewable energy resources with hands on exercises.The team based activities involve graduate students, Research Experience Undergraduate and Pre- college student's working in a team based environment to validate different functions in automation for Distributed Generation (DG) based network for load and voltage control. The research and education opportunity has helped to retain the interest of the students and faculty in the area of power systems which has led to being awarded best paper awards at the Howard University research Day. The skill set for modeling and simulation which involves power system with different models under uncertainties has been achieved by the students who participated in the project.
